text: 100% agree, it's just hard to intentionally torch your own career because you want to make a difference. In my last position I was about milking the ML hype in genomics. In my current one I'm developing boring, non-state-of-the-art software to aid influenza pandemic protection. Guess which job is best for the CV.

elements.text: 100% agree, it's just hard to intentionally torch your own career because you want to make a difference. In my last position I was about milking the ML hype in genomics. In my current one I'm developing boring, non-state-of-the-art software to aid influenza pandemic protection. Guess which job is best for the CV.

text:
I can relate in some ways. I know a guy though, who has made an entire career out of being a "data influencer" (he owns a small company too), by teaching people excel and sql. It's hilarious to super nerds but he's pretty successful and his ROI's are solid.

Let's be real - most of this data thing will pop like the web bubble did as soon as it becomes normal for domain experts to take a few stats classes and an ML class. Also when the VC people realize all the startups they bought haven't produced an AGI, >80% of the products are dead in the water, and the ML literature is approaching a garbage heap that needs standardization. Give it 2-3 more years. Ride the wave, but be weary of the ships of fools or something.

text: Thanks a lot! I'm a STEM student and I see a good amount of people going for quantity (and I feel conflicted not having as much). Not anymore though ;-)
